title: 6-Axis Robotic Arm
author: Michael Rodriguez
summary: Design and construction of a 6-axis robotic arm using 3D printing, servo motors, and inverse kinematics.

content.introduction: The 6-Axis Robotic Arm project combines mechanical engineering, electronics, and programming to create a fully functional robotic arm. Students learn about 3D design, kinematics, and robot control while building a desktop-sized industrial-style robot.

sections.title: Design and Manufacturing
sections.content: The arm is designed in Fusion 360 and manufactured using 3D printing. We use PETG for structural components and TPU for grippers. The design incorporates six degrees of freedom, allowing for complex movements and precise positioning. Students learn about mechanical design principles, stress analysis, and additive manufacturing.
sections.imageDescription: 3D CAD model and printed parts of the robotic arm

sections.title: Electronics and Control
sections.content: The arm uses six high-torque servo motors controlled by an Arduino Mega. We implement inverse kinematics algorithms to enable intuitive control of the end effector position. A custom PCB handles power distribution and motor control, while a Python interface allows for programming complex movement sequences.
